articles.headline: Lift ‘Threats,’ Obama Insists, Spurning Talks
articles.snippet: President Obama urged Republicans to fund and reopen the government but raised the possibility of short-term measures to facilitate broader negotiations.
articles.abstract: President Obama urged Republicans to fund and reopen the government but raised the possibility of short-term measures to facilitate broader negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama intensified his pressure on House Republicans on Tuesday, calling on them to “lift these threats from our families and our businesses” as the federal government remained shuttered into a second week and the possibility that the United States would default on its debts grew closer.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Starbucks Aims to Move Beyond Beans
articles.snippet: With recent acquisitions, the chain is expanding its offerings in an attempt to broaden its appeal beyond coffee drinks.
articles.abstract: With recent acquisitions, the chain is expanding its offerings in an attempt to broaden its appeal beyond coffee drinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In a suburb due east of Los Angeles, Starbucks is opening a $70 million, state-of-the-art plant that will produce cold-pressed juices.

articles.headline: Oil Shocks Ahead? Probably Not
articles.snippet: American consumers are using less gasoline, and despite upheaval in the Middle East and elsewhere, domestic oil production and other sources should ease supply issues for now.
articles.abstract: American consumers are using less gasoline, and despite upheaval in the Middle East and elsewhere, domestic oil production and other sources should ease supply issues for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — OVER the last few months, as an Egyptian government fell in a coup, the United States considered an attack on Syria and disgruntled Libyan terminal guards blocked oil exports, the only predictable news was the rise in oil prices to levels not seen in more than two years.

articles.headline: New Corporate Tax Shelter: A Merger Abroad
articles.snippet: More large American corporations are reducing their tax bill by buying a foreign company and effectively renouncing their United States citizenship.
articles.abstract: More large American corporations are reducing their tax bill by buying a foreign company and effectively renouncing their United States citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at a California chip maker, Applied Materials, highlighted a number of advantages in announcing a merger recently with a smaller Japanese rival, but an important one was barely mentioned: lower taxes.

articles.headline: Obama to Pick Yellen as Leader of Fed, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s No. 2 official, would become the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve, and the first Democrat to get the job since 1987.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s No. 2 official, would become the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve, and the first Democrat to get the job since 1987.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate Janet L. Yellen as chairwoman of the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, White House officials said Tuesday night, ending an unusually prolonged and public search to fill one of the most important economic policy-making jobs in the world.

articles.headline: Stubborn Skills Gap in America’s Work Force
articles.snippet: A new report says workers in the United States are falling behind their global peers in key measures, despite the fact that American employers pay a large wage premium for skilled labor.
articles.abstract: A new report says workers in the United States are falling behind their global peers in key measures, despite the fact that American employers pay a large wage premium for skilled labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the few things that nearly everyone in Washington agrees on is that American workers are the best.

articles.headline: SAC Is Said to Weigh Plea Deal in Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are said to have offered the fund a deal to plead guilty and pay a penalty of about $2 billion. If SAC does not accept, a much larger fine is threatened.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are said to have offered the fund a deal to plead guilty and pay a penalty of about $2 billion. If SAC does not accept, a much larger fine is threatened.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of fighting the government’s insider trading case tooth and nail, the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is leaning toward admitting criminal wrongdoing and agreeing to pay a record financial penalty to resolve the charges, according to two people briefed on the deliberations.

articles.headline: Deadlock Worry Jolts the Market for T-Bills
articles.snippet: The price of a one-month bill rose to its highest level since 2008, a sign that investors are worrying more about the stalemate in Washington.
articles.abstract: The price of a one-month bill rose to its highest level since 2008, a sign that investors are worrying more about the stalemate in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political impasse over the debt ceiling roiled a closely watched corner of the bond market on Tuesday, pushing up the price the government paid to borrow money for a month to its highest level since 2008, more than doubling from just a day earlier.

articles.headline: Many in G.O.P. Offer Theory: Default Wouldn’t Be That Bad
articles.snippet: Leaders in both parties are counting on the prospect of an economic meltdown to pull Republicans into line, but a surprisingly broad section of the party says a default poses little threat.
articles.abstract: Leaders in both parties are counting on the prospect of an economic meltdown to pull Republicans into line, but a surprisingly broad section of the party says a default poses little threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Richard Burr, Republican of North Carolina, a reliable friend of business on Capitol Hill and no one’s idea of a bomb thrower, isn’t buying the apocalyptic warnings that a default on United States government debt would lead to a global economic cataclysm.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Say Libya Approved Commando Raids
articles.snippet: Libyan officials denounced the operation to capture a senior Qaeda militant, but American officials say the raid, and another to seize a suspect in the 2011 attack on a diplomatic mission, had Libya’s tacit approval.
articles.abstract: Libyan officials denounced the operation to capture a senior Qaeda militant, but American officials say the raid, and another to seize a suspect in the 2011 attack on a diplomatic mission, had Libya’s tacit approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Libyan government in recent weeks tacitly approved two American commando operations in its country, according to senior American officials, one to capture a senior militant from Al Qaeda and another to seize a militia leader suspected of carrying out the Sept. 11, 2012, attacks on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Yellen’s Path From Liberal Theorist to Fed Voice for Jobs
articles.snippet: Janet Yellen, President Obama’s pick to run the Federal Reserve, has backed aggressive steps to promote employment but shown only limited willingness to tolerate higher inflation.
articles.abstract: Janet Yellen, President Obama’s pick to run the Federal Reserve, has backed aggressive steps to promote employment but shown only limited willingness to tolerate higher inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — When the economists Janet L. Yellen and George A. Akerlof hired a baby sitter for their son in the early 1980s, they decided to pay more than the going wage. They reasoned that a happier baby sitter would provide better care.

articles.headline: With New Abortion Restrictions, Ohio Walks a Narrow Legal Line
articles.snippet: Ohio has become a laboratory for a political strategy designed to discourage women from getting abortions and hamper clinic operations, without flagrantly violating Supreme Court precedent.
articles.abstract: Ohio has become a laboratory for a political strategy designed to discourage women from getting abortions and hamper clinic operations, without flagrantly violating Supreme Court precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Angela H., married with two children, became pregnant accidentally and, after medical complications during her last pregnancy and severe postpartum depression, said neither she nor her family was ready for another child.
